title: How Long Until My Kid Can Do Mental Math with Soroban? Don't Expect What I Expected
description: I thought my son would be calculating in his head within weeks. The real timeline was different – here's what actually happened.
keywords: how long to learn mental math
imageAlt: Child practicing mental math after learning Soroban

content.intro: When I signed my son up for Soroban, I expected results in weeks. "He'll be doing mental math by next month," I thought. Month one: nothing. Month two: still using the abacus. Month three: I started doubting. Here's the real timeline – and what I wish I'd known.

sections.text: I'd seen YouTube videos of kids rattling off answers. Flash cards flying. Mental math like magic. I assumed that came quick.
Reality check: Those kids had been practicing for years. Not weeks.

items: **Month 1:** Learning to represent numbers on the abacus. No calculating yet.
**Month 2-3:** Simple addition and subtraction ON the abacus. Still looking at beads.
**Month 4-5:** Starting to need the abacus less for simple problems.
**Month 6:** First signs of mental calculation – closing eyes, visualizing beads.

sections.text: Average time to basic mental math: 6-9 months of consistent practice. Not weeks.
Why It Takes Longer Than You Think
Soroban isn't memorizing multiplication tables. It's rewiring how the brain processes numbers. That takes time.
Think of it like learning an instrument. You don't play concertos after a month of piano. But the foundation you build makes everything else possible.
What I Tell Other Parents Now

items: **Celebrate small wins:** First time getting 10 problems right? Big deal!
**Consistency beats intensity:** 15 minutes daily trumps 2 hours on weekends
**Trust the process:** It's working even when you can't see it yet

sections.text: If you're at month 2-3 and feeling discouraged, you're right on schedule. The payoff comes later – and it's worth the wait.

faq.question: My child has been practicing for 4 months with no mental math. Is something wrong?
faq.answer: No. This is normal. Mental math (Anzan) typically starts around month 5-6 for most kids. Some take longer. Patience is key.

faq.question: Can my child ever catch up to kids who started younger?
faq.answer: For practical purposes, yes. Kids who start at 8 might take slightly longer to reach the same level, but they'll get there. For competition levels, starting younger does help.

faq.question: How do I know if my child is progressing normally?
faq.answer: If they're improving at all – even slowly – they're progressing. The Sorokid app tracks this for you and adjusts difficulty automatically.
